what: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists
title: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists
text: MexBrewer package color palettes inspired works Mexican painters muralists. package motivated draws heavily code Blake R. Mills’s {MetBrewer}, package color palettes form Metropolitan Museum Art New York. structure package coding, like {MetBrewer}, based {PNWColors} {wesanderson}.

title: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists

title: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists
text: Invoke data sets used examples: Join population statistics state boundaries: Distribution population geographic region Mexico:  Percentage population speak indigenous language 2020 state:
code: library(aRtsy) # Koen Derks' package for generative art  library(flametree) # Danielle Navarro's package for generative art library(MexBrewer) library(sf) library(tidyverse) data("mx_estados") # Simple features object with the boundaries of states in Mexico data("df_mxstate_2020") # Data from {mxmaps }with population statistics at the state level mx_estados <- mx_estados |>   left_join(df_mxstate_2020 |>               #Percentage of population that speak an indigenous language               mutate(pct_ind_lang = indigenous_language/pop * 100) |>                dplyr::transmute(pop2020 = pop,                                am2020 = afromexican,                                state_name,                                 pct_ind_lang),             by = c("nombre" = "state_name")) ggplot(data = mx_estados,        aes(x = region, y = pop2020, fill = region)) +   geom_boxplot() +   scale_fill_manual(values = mex.brewer("Concha", n = 5)) +   theme_minimal() ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = mx_estados,           aes(fill = pct_ind_lang),           color = "white",           size = 0.08) +   scale_fill_gradientn(colors = mex.brewer("Tierra")) +   theme_minimal()

title: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists
text: following three images created using {flametree} package.
code: # pick some colours shades <- MexBrewer::mex.brewer("Vendedora") |>   as.vector()  # data structure defining the trees dat <- flametree_grow(seed = 3563,                       time = 11,                        trees = 10)  # draw the plot dat |>    flametree_plot(     background = shades[1],     palette = shades[2:length(shades)],      style = "nativeflora"   ) # pick some colours shades <- MexBrewer::mex.brewer("Concha") |>   as.vector()  # data structure defining the trees dat <- flametree_grow(seed = 3536,                       time = 8,                        trees = 6)  # draw the plot dat |>    flametree_plot(     background = shades[1],     palette = rev(shades[2:length(shades)]),      style = "wisp"   ) # pick some colours shades <- MexBrewer::mex.brewer("Maiz") |>   as.vector()  # data structure defining the trees dat <- flametree_grow(seed = 3653,                       time = 8,                        trees = 6)  # draw the plot dat |>    flametree_plot(     background = shades[1],     palette = shades[2:length(shades)],      style = "minimal"   )

title: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists
text: following three images created using {aRtsy} package. Functions:  Mosaic:  Mandelbrot’s set:
code: my_formula <- list(   x = quote(runif(1, -1, 1) * x_i^2 - sin(y_i^2)),   y = quote(runif(1, -1, 1) * y_i^3 - cos(x_i^2)) )  canvas_function(colors = mex.brewer("Atentado"),                  polar = FALSE,                 by = 0.005,                 formula = my_formula) canvas_squares(colors = mex.brewer("Alacena"),                 cuts = 20,                ratio = 1.5,                resolution = 200,                noise = TRUE) canvas_mandelbrot(colors = mex.brewer("Naturaleza"),                    zoom = 8,                   iterations = 200,                   resolution = 500)

title: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists
text: plots adaptations Meghan Harris’s artsy waves. Create data frames wave functions: Define function convert single wave set n waves. function takes data frame wave function returns data frame n waves: Create layered waves using data frames wave functions : Plot layered waves using cartesian coordinates palette Ofrenda:  Plot layered waves using polar coordinates palette Atentado:
code: ##Set up the "range" on the x axis for horizontal waves===== wave_theta <- seq(from = -pi,                   to = -0,                    by = 0.01)   # Create waves using functions wave_1 <- data.frame(x = wave_theta) |>    mutate(y = (sin(x) * cos(2 * wave_theta) + exp(x * 2)))  wave_2 <- data.frame(x = wave_theta) |>   mutate(y = (0.5 * sin(x) * cos(2.0 * wave_theta) + exp(x)) - 0.5) # Creating a function for iterations====  wave_maker <- function(wave_df, n, shift){      #Create an empty list to store our multiple dataframes(waves)#   wave_list<- list()      #Create a for loop to iteratively make "n" waves shifted a distance `shift` from each other #   for(i in seq_along(1:n)){          wave_list[[i]] <- wave_df |>       mutate(y = y - (shift * i),              group = i)     }      #return the completed data frame to the environment#   return(bind_rows(wave_list)) } wave_layers <- rbind(wave_1 |>                        wave_maker(n = 5,                                    shift = 0.075),                      wave_2 |>                        wave_maker(n = 5,                                    shift = 0.075) |>                        mutate(group = group + 5)) # adjust the group counter to identify waves uniquely ggplot(wave_layers) +   geom_rect(aes(xmin = -pi,                  xmax = -0.0,                  ymin = min(y) - 0.50,                 ymax = max(y) + 0.30 ),             size = 2.5,             color = mex.brewer("Ofrenda")[6],             fill = mex.brewer("Ofrenda")[4]) +   geom_rect(aes(xmin = -pi,                  xmax = -0.0,                  ymin = min(y) - 0.50,                 ymax = max(y) + 0.30 ),             size = 1,             color = "black",             fill = NA) +   geom_ribbon(aes(x,                    ymin = y - 0.025 * 4 * x,                   ymax = y + 0.015 * 10 * x,                    group = group,                    fill = group),               color = "black",               size = 0.5) +    scale_fill_gradientn(colors = mex.brewer("Ofrenda"))+   theme_void() +   theme(legend.position = "none") #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. ggplot(wave_layers) +   geom_rect(aes(xmin = -pi,                  xmax = -0.0,                  ymin = min(y) - 0.45,                 ymax = max(y) + 0.30 ),             size = 2.5,             color = mex.brewer("Atentado")[6],             fill = mex.brewer("Atentado")[3]) +   geom_rect(aes(xmin = -pi,                  xmax = -0.0,                  ymin = min(y) - 0.45,                 ymax = max(y) + 0.30 ),             size = 1,             color = "black",             fill = NA) +   geom_ribbon(aes(x,                    ymin = y - 0.025 * 4 * x,                   ymax = y + 0.015 * 10 * x,                    group = group,                    fill = group),               color = "black",               size = 0.5) +    scale_fill_gradientn(colors = mex.brewer("Atentado")) +   coord_polar(theta = "x",                 start = 0,                direction = 1,                clip = "on") +   theme_void() +   theme(legend.position = "none")

what: MexBrewer: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists — MexBrewer-package
title: MexBrewer: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists — MexBrewer-package
text: Color palettes inspired works Mexican painters muralists. package includes functions return vectors colors also functions use color fill scales 'ggplot2' visualizations.

title: MexBrewer: Color Palettes Inspired by Works of Mexican Painters and Muralists — MexBrewer-package
text: Maintainer: Antonio Páez paezha@mcmaster.ca (ORCID)

title: Complete list of palettes — MexPalettes
text: Use names(MexPalettes) return possible palette names. Current choices : Alacena, Atentado, Aurora, Casita1, Casita2, Casita3, Concha, Frida, Huida,  Maiz, Naturaleza, Ofrenda, Revolucion, Ronda, Taurus1, Taurus2,Tierra, Vendedora. Use mex.brewer construct palettes.

title: Complete list of palettes — MexPalettes
text: object class list length 18.

title: Mexican 2020 states dataset — df_mxstate_2020
text: data.frame containing population estimates Mexican states 2020

title: Mexican 2020 states dataset — df_mxstate_2020
text: object class data.frame 32 rows 11 columns.

title: Mexican 2020 states dataset — df_mxstate_2020
text: data.frame

title: Mexican 2020 states dataset — df_mxstate_2020
text: region INEGI code state state_name short state name (e.g. Coahuila) state_name_official Official state name (e.g. Coahuila de Zaragoza) state_abbr state abbreviation state_abbr_official official state abbreviation (can awkward use Chis Chiapas) according INEGI. year 2015, year Conteo data sourced pop total state population according Censo 2020 pop_male male population according Censo 2020 pop_female female population according Censo 2020 afromexican afromexican population according Censo 2020 indigenous_language Number persons speak indigenous language according Censo 2020

title: Mexican 2020 states dataset — df_mxstate_2020
text: Population estimates taken Censo 2020.

what: Continuous MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-continuous
title: Continuous MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-continuous
text: Functions scale_color_mex_c scale_fill_mex_c continuous scales enable use MexBrewer colors ggplot2 continuous scales.

title: Continuous MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-continuous
code: scale_color_mex_c(palette_name, direction = 1, ...)  scale_colour_mex_c(palette_name, direction = 1, ...)  scale_fill_mex_c(palette_name, direction = 1, ...)

title: Continuous MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-continuous
text: palette_name Name Palette. Choices : Alacena, Atentado, Aurora, Casita1, Casita2, Casita3, Concha, Frida, Huida,  Maiz,  Naturaleza,Ofrenda, Revolucion, Ronda, Taurus1, Taurus2,Tierra, Vendedora. direction Sets order colors. Default palette 1. direction -1, palette color order reversed ... arguments passed scale_color_gradientn

title: Continuous MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-continuous
text: ScaleContinuous object can added ggplot object

what: Discrete MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-discrete
title: Discrete MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-discrete
text: Functions scale_color_mex_d scale_fill_mex_d enable use MexBrewer colors ggplot2 discrete scales.

title: Discrete MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-discrete
code: scale_color_mex_d(palette_name, direction = 1, override.order = FALSE, ...)  scale_colour_mex_d(palette_name, direction = 1, override.order = FALSE, ...)  scale_fill_mex_d(palette_name, direction = 1, override.order = FALSE, ...)

title: Discrete MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-discrete
text: palette_name Name Palette. Choices : Alacena, Atentado, Aurora, Casita1, Casita2, Casita3, Concha, Frida, Huida,  Maiz,  Naturaleza,Ofrenda, Revolucion, Ronda, Taurus1, Taurus2,Tierra, Vendedora. direction Sets order colors. Default palette 1. direction -1, palette color order reversed override.order Colors picked palette maximize readability aesthetics. means colors always selected sequential order full palette. override.order set TRUE, colors selected sequential order full palette instead. Default FALSE. ... arguments passed discrete_scale

title: Discrete MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-discrete
text: ScaleDiscrete object can added ggplot object

title: Discrete MexBrewer scales for use with ggplot2 — ggplot2-scales-discrete
code: library(ggplot2) ggplot(data=iris, aes(x=Species, y=Sepal.Length, fill=Species)) + geom_violin() + scale_fill_mex_d("Aurora")

title: Mex Palette Generator — mex.brewer
text: handful color palettes Mexican muralists. Complete list palette colors works inspired can found .

title: Mex Palette Generator — mex.brewer
code: mex.brewer(   palette_name,   n,   type = c("discrete", "continuous"),   direction = c(1, -1),   override.order = FALSE )

title: Mex Palette Generator — mex.brewer
text: palette_name Name Palette. Choices : Alacena, Atentado, Aurora, Casita1, Casita2, Casita3, Concha, Frida, Huida,  Maiz,  Naturaleza,Ofrenda, Revolucion, Ronda, Taurus1, Taurus2,Tierra, Vendedora. n Number desired colors. number requested colors beyond scope palette, colors automatically interpolated. n provided, length palette used. type Either "continuous" "discrete". Use continuous want automatically interpolate colors. direction Sets order colors. Default palette 1. direction -1, palette color order reversed override.order Colors picked palette maximize readability aesthetics. means colors always selected sequential order full palette. override.order set TRUE, colors selected sequential order full palette instead. Default FALSE.

title: Mex Palette Generator — mex.brewer
text: vector colors use visualization tasks
